Posts.Content: I too have just been scheduled for an ultra sound after they found a 1 cm lump with spiculated margins. They are calling this "suspicious", although my doctor said it is nothing about 85% of the time. The "spiculated margins" thing has me worried a little. Has anyone had experience with finding a lump with edges that wasn't cancerous? I am not totally freaked, but a little surprised. Have had a ton of tests lately and all were great, except the mammogram, which I didnt even give a second thought.
Posts.Title: First Mammogram Results (need some advice) 1 2

Posts.Content: Thanks for the well wishes, Phyl. I am a little freaked tonight but will know more tomorrow.
Posts.Title: First Mammogram Results (need some advice) 1 2

Posts.Content: I am back from the mammogram ultrasound. They are pretty sure it is cancer. It was difficult for them to detect at first. Apparently about 3-4-8mm in size. Dont know if that includes the tendril like things I saw on the original mammobgram Naturally I am totallly freaking. They couldnt really answer any of my questions at the hospital. Questions like: -Since it is so small can I assume it is early stages and easily treatable. -Does this mean possibly I have cancer in other areas of my body. -Does this explain my tiredness over the last couple of years. -Should I tell my aging parents? (I did talk to the gyno while I was writing this) He said it would be very unusual to have it metastisize from other parts of my body or to other parts from the breast. He was very upbeat about options and treatment He said it wouldnt explain the fatigue and lack of stamina I originally started all the testing for. DRAT!!!! Are there any other good educational sites on breast cancer besides this one? Has anyone had a similar experience and can offer that?
Posts.Title: First Mammogram Results (need some advice) 1 2

Posts.Content: From what I have read the spiculated margins can be indicative of a malignancy, but not always. Rounded is better, apparently. I was supposed to wait until next week also, but muscled my way into the ultrasound tomorrow. It is somewhat ironic that I was so faithful in my mammograms until about two years ago and now they find something. I had been under going a lot of other testing and the mammagram was just an aside we threw in there. Hopefully if it is cancerous, it is early enough to do something about it. May explain why I have been so tired for a couple of years. That was the original symptom we were trying to solve. I am a little freaked, but mostly irritated at myself, for not keeping up the yearly mammograms. I also have dense breasts so it is possible they did not see this until now. Keep a positive thought for me.
Posts.Title: First Mammogram Results (need some advice) 1 2

Posts.Content: Caligirl. Thanks for posting this and asking your doctor about the spiculated margins. That was really thoughtful and helps me a lot. The GP and gyno said the same thing. Maybe only 10-15 % are malignant. At least we may have caught it early. I do not know if they will order a biopsy or not. Today is the mammogram ultrasound and I guess they will decide from there. I have already made up my mind it is probably something, which isnt my usual attitude. Just so ironic I would slack on the mammograms that I used to be so faithful about. I know, beating myself up doesnt help. Looks like great support here and I really appreciate it. Your news sounds pretty positive, since it doesnt seem to be acting malignant. I can not feel mine. It is near the nipple area. Hope to know more later.
Posts.Title: First Mammogram Results (need some advice) 1 2

Posts.Content: It could be so many things and yet nothing. I would have it checked out as soon as possible. Could be a muscle strain, a breast issue,even a heart issue. Many times this kinds of things are nothing but call the doctor for peae of mind.
Posts.Title: Severe Breast Pain

Posts.Content: It is difficult to say and of course we arent doctors although we feel like it sometimes. If he is talking about spiculated margins..the legs or thread parts, I know they like to biopsy these because cancerous lesions often do have those type of characteristics, but not always. The fact that you have had it for awhile could be good news. Often non cancerous lesions will react to hormones. Therefore if you were having more normal periods again, it could cause the old lump to grow. Still I wouldnt get too worked up until you have the biopsy. Often these things are nothing.
Posts.Title: Lump is spindle-shaped? What does this mean?

Posts.Content: Hang in and keep getting things checked and ask lots of questions. Research helps too. I had an aunt on both sides die in their 50's from BC. A paternal great aunt too. That is why I always had the mammograms. Still I am shocked and po'd I have it too.
Posts.Title: Lump is spindle-shaped? What does this mean?

Posts.Content: Good for you to stay on the docs. It is frustrating when they say one thing and then the other. Kind of what I am going through now. First it was just one small lesion. Now it is three and a benign in the other breast. So Monday's surgery is getting more invasive by the minute..yuk!! Glad you were brave and followed your instincts and they got it all.
Posts.Title: Lump is spindle-shaped? What does this mean?

Posts.Content: Not too bad. I was surprised it was not more painful. They do numb you with a local, like at the dentist. The doctor and attending nurse were just so wonderful. Held my hand and told me everything that was going to happen. My lumpectomy is scheduled for Monday. Had the MRI today. Keep in touch and let us know how it goes. Just keep nudging the ball forward. Sometimes it is overwhelming and that's okay too.
Posts.Title: Lump is spindle-shaped? What does this mean?

Posts.Content: The surgeon has not mentioned anything about not having BP in certain arms. I had a lupect, if that makes any difference. The nodes came out of the right armpit. She only took two, I believe, for sentinel node testing. That area is a little numb but it seems to be getting better. The scar is kind of annoying in the hot weather, because my sweaty arm keeps sticking to it.
Posts.Title: Ductile Carcinoma 1 2 3

Posts.Content: Cj and Jezzie, Thanks so much for replying. I am all over the map emotionally and the research is also making my head spin. They say it is under 1 cm and hormone positive. I didnt know about radiation recall. that is a little scary. I am not that comfortable with the thought of radiation or the chemotherapy. Jezzie, Do you have to take the Femora forever? I was just curious about that. I have had a lot of negative reactions to drugs over the years and worry that I will not take well to radiation or chemo. Hoping there is some slim chance I will need neither, but maybe that is not possible. CJ, are you comfortable telling me more about your diagnosis. I thought it might help me to decide between masectomy and lupectomy. LIke size etc. Thanks so much for your thoughts and prayers. They mean a lot to me.
Posts.Title: Ductile Carcinoma 1 2 3

Posts.Content: Got the call today. That is what I have. All the doctors are very optimistic, but of course, I am totally freaked. Wondering if this is why I have been so tired for two years. They all say "no". I havent told any of my family. There are a lot of decisions to make. Lumpectomy or masectomy? It is pretty small, but did exceed outside of the duct. They dont know about the lymph nodes yet. Say they wont know until surgergy. So silly me, is ****** off, that after all I did to take care of myself this is what i get. What was the point? Yea I know that is stupid. Next I am worried about it incinveniencing my active lifestyle which includes starting my little boat motor with that arm. How long are you out of commission from a lumpectormy or masectomy. Then it is my pride and how I dont want people to know. I could go on and on but right now just trying to get used to the whole idea. My appointment with the surgeon is Wednesday and with a second opinion on July 2nd. WOuld love to hear from people that have been through it.
Posts.Title: Ductile Carcinoma 1 2 3

Posts.Content: Thanks so much for responding CJ. My head is hurting and spinning right now. I am mentally leaning towards the lupectomy because it sounds like a less invasive surgery. Why did you choose the masectomy? I dont know all the lingo yet but I guss you are saying that you hormones recptors were positive and you had some in your lymph nodes. I am still on a steep learning curve. It seems so weird to me that they wont tell you about the lymph nodes until after the initial surgery. Seems like it sure would help to know about the lymph nodes going in. Why did you not want to do the radiation? I havent even told my family. I am not married and debating whether and or how to tell my poor aging parents. They each had a sister die of bc at my age. That is why I always got the mammograms. But I slacked off the last two years so also kicking myself. ARGGH!! So many negative feelings, which I know arent helping. Thanks so much for listening.
Posts.Title: Ductile Carcinoma 1 2 3

Posts.Content: Thanks, for the info and support KD. Yes, it is a subject we didnt want to become experts in. Sorry you had to go back so many times but glad they finally think they will have you on a good course. Yes, I am throwing a pity party lately and decided just to go with it. some of the reason may be I have wanted to keep this quiet. Maybe if more people knew I would have more support. Still that is my way and I have my reasons. Let us know how you are.
Posts.Title: Ductile Carcinoma 1 2 3

Posts.Content: I missed this post somehow. Thanks for the tip, Phyl on reducing the doses and radiation eetc. I will push for that. Everybody try to keep smiling.
Posts.Title: Ductile Carcinoma 1 2 3

Posts.Content: Suggi, I am sorry you have had such a hard time with it. I hope they will find some things that work for your treatment. It seems they come up with new treatments yearly for BC. I feel a little quilty that I have been very lucky so far. Nothing in the lymph nodes and clean margin. Stage1/Grade1. The only reason I am so lucky is because my gyno threw in a mammogram with a bunch of other tests we were doing to see if HRT would help some of my menopausal symptoms. That's out forever now!! I have had mammograms religiously since I was 37. I had two aunts and a great aunt die of breast cancer in their 50's or 60's. But I was a little overdo on the mammo in the last two years. They tell me it probably wouldnt have mattered, because it may not have been visible. My surgeon is talking about a clinical trial for women in the mid range oncotype scores. I do not know what my oncotype score is yet. The tissue sample was just sent out. Truthfully I hope it will be in the low numbers because then I will only have to do radiation and endocrine therapy. I was her2 postive. So I am over the intial shock and starting to feel like myself again. At least for now, before the next phase...the radiation.
Posts.Title: Ductile Carcinoma 1 2 3

Posts.Content: I had the squishy sound and feeling too. Doctor also said it is normal. It went away after about a week. It has been 2 weeks since my lupectomy and the breast is till slightly swollen. Everything looks pretty good though. Did have strange pains in strange places. Like a "stitch" type feeling around the rib on that side. LIke there wasnt enough skin and tissue to fully extend my arm. I have been stretching though and it is getting better. I am Stage1 Grade 1 invasive ductile with 9mm tumor. 55 years old
Posts.Title: Fluid in breast after having lump removed

Posts.Content: Thanks Again, CJ. Sorry about your daughter and they way the docs treated her and you. I was really kind of surprised to get that treatment. I figured those days were gone and these were women doctors and nurses. I am sure it is difficult on their end too. I looked up mammosite. It is a portal of radiation they place in side the area for a week. I would love to do that instead of the 6 weeks but there may be a problem with how close to the skin my tumor is. Apparently it is hard on the skin. So off to the counselor this morning. I will be prepared with the tissues. IT is difficult to see and say the word cancer. I still am in shock that I even have it since I always took good care of myself. I know that doesnt matter. I picked up my mammogram films to take to the second opinion person. I had forgotten how many mammograms I have had. Started in 1989 when I was 37 and had them at least every other year since. Me being me, I might actually look at those films myself. Would love to see if I can detect any difference. I slacked on my mammograms after late 2004, so that is a lesson to many hopefully, although they are still saying it may not have even been visible until recently. Have a good day, CJ. Thanks again.
Posts.Title: Ductile Carcinoma 1 2 3

Posts.Content: Jezzie and Phyl, Thanks for the support and stories of how it went with you. I feel better lately. I guess because relatively speaking, the news is good. Of course that could all change. I am very leery of the chemo and radiation because I have always been sensitive to any medication or foreign process. It usually takes about half the dose of medicine to work with me. Maybe I can talk them into that. Yeah, right? The counselor appointment went well. She was very focused on what my goals would be while in cancer counseling. I said to deal with my emotions and keep living my life to the fullest. At 55, I dont want to waste away my days moping or in fear. I was like that before the BC. So I am very lucky that I have services available to me and insurance. I may be even feeling guilty for not being sicker when so many are. Boy, that is warped, I guess.
Posts.Title: Ductile Carcinoma 1 2 3

Posts.Content: CJ, Thanks once again for your valuable support and experience. I was at the hospital for almost three hours today. Various entities were talking to me before i finally saw the surgeon. While they were all good, I thought, on the whole, the practitioners and the surgeon talk too much and dont listen much. Has anyone else had that impression? Just me being stubborn, maybe. I had done a lot of research and felt for awhile they were talking down to me and explaining things I already knew, while I had other questions. Me, being me, I just interrupted eventually. Barring any other negative test results, they seemed pretty positive. They think it is Grade1/Stage1. Of course I will not know fully until lymph node testing. They want an MRI too, first. Apparently radiation is a given, but a slim possibility I could use something called a mammosite, sp?), that would be for less time but more intense. Has anyone had experience with that? They talked about tamoxifen or something like that maybe later. That final piece seems a little like overkill, but maybe I am missing something. So now waiting, waiting, waiting, as usual. That is the hardest part. That and trying to continue to live life fully in the meantime. In that vein I am gong to a cancer care counselor tomorrow. You have been so helpful and understanding. thank you so much. It means a lot to me. Beth
Posts.Title: Ductile Carcinoma 1 2 3

Posts.Content: I will. thanks. I think it is all just beginning to sink in as I am getting really depressed lately. [emailÂ protected]@ As cancer goes, right now, I am probably one of the lucky ones. Still I am going through a lot of emotion right now. Angry.... after all I did, which is an extremely healthy lifestyle, I still got it. Just feeling sorry for myself I guess. It has really shook me to the core. Sort of taken away my identity as the "healthy, fit, 55 year old".
Posts.Title: Ductile Carcinoma 1 2 3

Posts.Content: Wow, Phyl, Glad your treatment is over. Sorry to hear you are still feeling side effects. My latest is a lump at the sentinel node testing site. Hoping this is normal and will go away. The stitch feeling is getting better. Next doctor appointment is 8/9.
Posts.Title: Fluid in breast after having lump removed

Posts.Content: Yes, it does seem to be a little different than my proceedure. They did the biopsy first and like you, said they got the original tumor out. But they wanted to schedule an MRI and the lupectomy to get any other cancerous areas around the original tumor and to get what they call "clear margins". That is why I am surprised they went right to the sentinel node testing. Usually this is done during the lupectomy. An Mri can detect very small possible cancers. It turned out I had a little activity in front of and behind the orignal tumor. So they took out a rectangular section and checked for clear margins. They did the snb while I was out for the lupect. and got the results immediatley. No node involvement. Now I am waiting to hear what is the next step. Usually radiation first and then one or both of the following; chemo/hormone therapy. Yes the tumor was cancer, but well differianted and Stage 1. Hope that helps. You might ask your doctor about an MRI and other diagnostic tools and whether he plans to do a lupectomy. Ask him about the clear margins.
Posts.Title: results of excisional biopsy...not what I expected

Posts.Content: Sounds somewhat similarc to my situation. I did not find the lump or did anyone else. It came up on routine mammogram. I am surprised that they want to do the sentinel node biopsy without first an MRI and possible lupectomy. Did I miss something here? Still it all sounds very positive, although it will be scary for you, while you wait for all the tests and results. Hope you can take some comfort in the fact they got it early. I was sure my nodes would be positive because I have felt so bad for a couple of years. But they were not. Someimtes we expect the worst. Have they talked to you about other treatment options like radiation, chemo, hormone therapy? All scary thoughts. Give yourself time to digest it all. You are just starting on the journey, but there will be people to help you along.
Posts.Title: results of excisional biopsy...not what I expected
